case_vignette: A 36-year-old male with a past medical history of poorly controlled Crohn's disease presents for evaluation of a painful non-healing wound on the left lower leg! Patient endorses a pus bump developing on the left leg two months ago which he initially thought was a spider bite but eventually popped open! He was seen at urgent care a month ago and received one week course of cephalexin without any improvement! Local debridement attempts at bedside by the urgent care provider resulted in significant expansion of the ulcer! Physical examination reveals a well demarcated ovoid ulcer on the left distal shin with violaceous, rolled borders and cribriform base with yellow-red exudate!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful non-healing wound on my left lower leg with a yellow-red discharge.
How long have you had this wound for?
I have had the wound for about two months.
Do you have any pre-existing conditions such as diabetes or vascular disease?
I have a history of poorly controlled Crohn's disease.
Have you had any previous similar wounds or skin issues elsewhere on your body?
No, I have not had similar wounds or skin issues elsewhere on my body.
Have you been receiving any specific treatment for your Crohn's disease recently?
I'm sorry, but I haven't mentioned any specific recent treatments for my Crohn's disease in the information I've given.
Is there any family history of skin conditions or autoimmune disorders?
I haven't mentioned any family history of skin conditions or autoimmune disorders.
Has the wound shown any signs of improvement with any treatments so far?
No, there has been no improvement with the treatments so far; the wound even expanded after local debridement attempts.
**Final Diagnosis:** Pyoderma gangrenosum

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with a non-healing wound on their left lower leg, characterized by a yellow-red discharge. The wound has persisted for approximately two months. The patient has a history of poorly controlled Crohn's disease but has not reported having similar wounds or skin issues elsewhere on their body. Additionally, the patient has not disclosed any specific recent treatments for Crohn's disease nor has any family history of skin conditions or autoimmune disorders been mentioned. The patient reports no improvement with treatments so far; in fact, the wound expanded after local debridement attempts.
